'''Batkhela''' ({{lang-ps|'''بټ خيله'''}}, {{lang-ur|بٹ خیلہ}}) is the main tehsil, city and capital of [[Malakand District]], [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa]], [[Pakistan]]. According to the 1998 census, the population of Batkhela is 38,222,{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} and it is estimated to be 39,703 according to the World Gazetteer.<ref name=gazet>{{cite web|url=http://world-gazetteer.com/wg.php?x%3D1230861383%26men%3Dgpro%26lng%3Den%26des%3Dgamelan%26geo%3D-172%26srt%3Dnpan%26col%3Dabcdefghinoq%26msz%3D1500%26pt%3Dc%26va%3D%26geo%3D448657197 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-08-03 |url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120218104102/http://world-gazetteer.com/wg.php?x=1230861383&men=gpro&lng=en&des=gamelan&geo=-172&srt=npan&col=abcdefghinoq&msz=1500&pt=c&va=&geo=448657197 |archivedate=18 February 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref> Batkhela is a popular business city in [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa]] province. One water canal that pours into a small dam in Jaban area is main source of electricity production.
Batkhela General Civil Headquarters Hospital is the main hospital of the district Malakand. Batkhela main bazaar is more than 2 kilometres long; there are no intersections (junctions) so no traffic lights. Therefore, it is the longest bazaar in Pakistan also in Asia that has no traffic lights or junctions (intersections) on it.<ref name=" Pattan Development Organization ">{{Cite book| authorlink= Pattan Development Organization | title= Malakand District: socio-political profile = Pattan Development Organization | year=2006| location=Islamabad| lccn=2007379799}}</ref><ref name=" Khan ">{{Cite book|author=Mohammad Nawaz Khan|title= Malakand: A journey through history |publisher= Gandhara Markaz |year=1995|page=12|asin=B0006FBFNK}}</ref>
==History==
===Etymology===
During the [[Ashoka]] and [[Kanishka]] Empires Batkhela was ruled by a leader named Butt hence city has given the name Batkhela.
[[File:Batkhela 2014-12-24.jpg|right|thumb|Batkhela water canal]] [[Image:District Head Quarter Hospital Batkhela OPD.jpg|right|thumb|200px| District Headquarters Hospital Batkhela OPD]] [[Image:District Head Quarter Hospital Batkhela Casualty.jpg|left|thumb|200px| District Headquarters Hospital Batkhela Casualty]]
===Early history===
[[File:Malakand division.JPG|left|thumb|200px|Batkhela Rural side]]
When [[Mahmud of Ghazni]] (997-1030) was attacking India against the Hindus, during this time one of his army leaders Pir Khushal assailed Batkhela, during the course of this assault most of his soldiers were sunk in a big marsh at a place called Ghelai in Batkhela. However, soldiers of his army that survived have preferred to stay in this region. They have not only changed the culture and customs of the local inhabitants but also exerted a strong influence on them to make them convert to [[Islam]].
[[Image:Amandara Head Works (Carpet water).jpg|right|thumb|200px|Amandara Head Works (water flow on floor)]]
Early in the 17th century an [[Afghanistan|Afghan]] tribe [[Yusufzai]] (Yusufzai [[Pathan]]) invaded Swat region <ref name="Rose, Ibbetson&Maclagan">{{Cite book|author=Horace Arthur Rose|author2=Sir Denzil Ibbetson|author3=Sir Edward Douglas Maclagan|last-author-amp=yes|title= Glossary of the Tribes and Castes of the Punjab and North West Frontier Province |publisher= Asian Educational Services, India |year=2006|page=125|ISBN=8120605055 }}</ref> under the leadership of Malik Ahmad Khan, during this period Batkhela was part of Swat valley. At the time Swat was ruled by a ruler named Raees and [[Swati (tribe)|Swati]] tribe was permanent inhabitant here. After the invasion most of the Swati tribesmen left this area and escaped to [[Hazara, Pakistan|Hazara]] region. It gave Yusufzai an opportunity to settle here permanently and they declared Thana region (currently part of Batkhela tehsil) is their administrative headquarters.
In the beginning three family classes of [[Yusufzai]] tribe were settled in Batkhela (Husain Khel, Ibrahim Khel and Nazrali Khel).
In March 1895 the [[British Empire]] invaded this region including Batkhela. Malak Mir Azam Khan of Ibrahim Khel was leading the army of Batkhela. A new political agency for Dir, Swat and [[Chitral]] was established.<ref name=" Richards">{{Cite book|author=Donald Sydney Richards|title= Pakistan The Savage Frontier: A History of the Anglo-Afghan Wars |publisher= Pan Books|year=2002|page=128|ISBN=0330420526}}</ref> The first officer to be placed in charge of the new Malakand Agency was Major [[Harold Arthur Deane]](1854–1908),<ref name="Hussain">{{Cite book|author=Rizwan Hussain|title= Pakistan and the Emergence of Islamic Militancy in Afghanistan |publisher= Ashgate |year=2005|page=36|ISBN=0754644340}}</ref><ref name=" Misra ">{{Cite book|author=Bankey Bihari Misra |title= The Unification and Division of India |publisher= OUP India |year=1991|page=128|ISBN=019562615X}}</ref><ref name="miller">{{Cite book|author=Charles Miller|title=KHYBER British India's North West Frontier The Story of an Imperial Migraine|publisher=McDonald and James|year=1977|page=[https://archive.org/details/khyberbritishind00mill/page/287 287]|ISBN=0025848607|url=https://archive.org/details/khyberbritishind00mill/page/287}}</ref><ref name=" Caroe">{{Cite book|author= Sir Olaf Kirkpatrick Caroe|title= The Pathans: 550 B.C.-A.D. 1957|publisher= OUP Pakistan |year=1976|page=386|ISBN=0195772210}}</ref><ref name=" Schofield">{{Cite book|author= Victoria Schofield|title= Afghan Frontier: Feuding and Fighting in Central Asia |publisher=Tauris Parke Paperbacks |year=2003|page=145|ISBN=1860648959}}</ref> later on 9 November 1901 Lieutenant Colonel Sir [[Harold Arthur Deane]] also became the first Chief Commissioner on the formation of the North-West Frontier Province (now [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa]]).<ref name=" Misra "/><ref name=" Caroe"/><ref name=" Schofield"/><ref name=" North">{{Cite book|author= Roger Edward Francis Guilford North|title= The literature of the North-West Frontier of India: A select bibliography |publisher= the University of California |year=1946|page=08|oclc=3131354}}</ref><ref name=" Riddick">{{Cite book|author=John F. Riddick|title= The History of British India: A Chronology |publisher= Praeger Publishers Inc. |year=2006|page=87|ISBN=0313322805}}</ref>
[[Image:Amandara Head Works (Batkhela Water Canal Bridge).jpg|right|thumb|200px|Amandara Head Works (Batkhela Water Canal Bridge)]]
This year when Batkhela was stormed by the 45th Sikhs after a fierce resistance Lieut.-Colonel McRae was the very first British army personnel to enter Batkhela.<ref name="Churchill">{{Cite book|author=Winston Churchill|title=The Story of The Malakand Field Force|publisher=Standard Publications, Inc.|year=2007|page=60|ISBN=1604245484}}</ref> Before 1895 Batkhela was invaded by different outsiders including Khan of Dir Rahmatullah Khan in 1869 and Wali-i-Dir/[[Nawab Muhammad Umara Khan]] as well as Swatis. On capturing Malakand Agency British army have decided to prevent this area permanently from these outside aggressions. The British rulers declare this area as ‘Malakand Protected Area’ (same as present) and so they prepared a police force called Malakand Levies.
Between 1895 and 1912 British made a huge impact on developmental works and infrastructure. They built roads (Batkhela to Chakdara), raised Chakdara and Malakand forts, set up Levies posts all over Malakand Agency, dug Upper Swat Canal and The Benton Tunnel (locally known as Tandail) and construct Headwork’s scheme at Batkhela, Churchill Picket and Jabban Power House. The most important of all is the Amandara (part of Batkhela) Irrigation Scheme (bridges) which were designed and built by British firm [[Ransomes & Rapier]], Ltd. Makers of [[Ipswich]] in 1912, which is still irrigating a vast land of Sama Tehsil, Mardan and Sawabi Districts and Chakdara area.
The British was ruling this area until the independence of Pakistan on 14 August 1947. All matters of the Tribal system was settled through ‘[[Jirga]] System’. The [[Frontier Crimes Regulation]] (FCR) system or status was established in 1974 here. Furthermore, regular laws prevailing and the settle laws of district were also extended. Under the FCR Political Agent exercised his powers as a supreme authority while regular courts were established (Civil & Crime courts) after the year 1974.
==Governance== Police in district Malakand are known as Levies and their head or commandant is District Coordination Officer (DCO). The current Tehsil Nazim of Batkhela is Fazal Wahid Lalagi [[Jamat Islami]].
==Geography== Batkhela is green city and Swat River is flowing in the middle of the city alongside N45. Batkhela is covered by tall hills from all sides and the most of famous peak of them is named ‘Barcharai’.
{{Geographic location |title = '''Neighbouring towns, villages and places.''' |Northwest = |North = Chakdara and Temargara |Northeast = |West = Dargai and Mardan |Centre = Batkhela |East = Barikot and Mingora |Southwest = |South = Palai |Southeast = }}
[[Image:Batkhela water canal alongside the main G.T. road.jpg|right|thumb|200px|Batkhela water canal alongside the main G.T. road (N45)]]
==Division== Politically Batkhela is divided into three union councils e.g. [[Upper Batkhela|Upper]], [[Middle Batkhela|middle]] and [[Lower Batkhela|lower]] Batkhela.
==Demography== At the time of the Pakistan Census 1998, according to the World Gazetteer, Batkhela had a total resident population of 39,703.<ref name="gazet"/> Data on religious beliefs across the town in the 1998 census show that 100% declared themselves to be Muslim.{{citation needed|date=February 2015}}
[[Image:Water Canal alongside N45.jpg|right|thumb|200px|Batkhela Water Canal alongside N45]]
==People and culture== More than 95% of Batkhela residents are Pashtuns, who are the indigenous inhabitants of the region, who follow the Pashtun code of conduct Pukhtunwali in its modern form.
==Education== A primary school was opened in Batkhela in 1915 by British while High school was opened in Thana (part of Batkhela tehsil) in 1935. Presently one degree college for boys, One degree college for women, two secondary schools for boys and one High Secondary School for girls are functioning. All the schools and colleges are affiliated with BISE Malakand. federal government school and college and several private schools are functioning ...
== Media == District Press Club Malakand at Batkhela has been functional since 1988 in a rented building while reporters attached with national, regional and local Print and Electronic media organizations have been performing their duties with devotion and sincerity. At the time the Press Club chairman Ran Nawaz Saghir works for Daily Express, Express News TV channel; General secretary Gohar Ali Gohar works for Daily Dawn, Daily Mashriq and Daily Nawa I Waqt; vice chairman Mohammad Rasool Rasa works for Daily Khabrain; joint secretary Tahir Khan for Jang, The News, Geo TV; Imran Zaryab for Samaa TV, Mashriq TV and Daily Ummat, Haji Gul for Aaj, Ihsan Sagar for Ausaf, the patron in chief Juma Rehman Daily Shamal, Hussain Khan for Aeen, Rafiullah Pardisi AAJ TV and Camera man Iqbal Jan works for different channels. [[thumb]] The former minister for information Mian Iftikhar Hussain and minister for finance Engineer Humayun Khan had approved funds for a well equipped press club building at Batkhela during their term. The remaining funds were approved by the sitting PTI lawmaker Shakil Khan. The construction work on the building has completed now. Soon it will be inaugurated making work of local journalists easier. The first ever ‘Monthly’ the Hidayat Nama was started by late Muhammad Islam Ajmali who has been regarded as founder of journalism in the area. Later on Mr Amjad Ali Khan started his monthly “Tasht” from Batkhela that was closed after a few years. The Monthly ‘Nazar’ of Gohar Ali Gohar also closed after two years of circulation. Rab Nawaz Saghir started his ‘Akas’ that closed too. Mr Ihsan ur Rehman Sagar started a monthly ‘Adrash’ which has been the first ever declared newspaper from the area. It was made a weekly sometime later and now a daily newspaper. A monthly ‘Nai Dunia’ is being published by Imran Zaryab from Batkhela and a weekly ‘Manend’ is also published by Wajid Ali at the moment. Apart from Batkhela, the Dargai Press Club is also functional and Zahir Shah has been its head for years. Similarly Junaid Iqbal also heads another press club at Thana .
